thread.title: EUROPE MARKETS: European Stocks On Track For Highest Close In A Week
thread.title_full: EUROPE MARKETS: European Stocks On Track For Highest Close In A Week

author: morningstar.com
title: EUROPE MARKETS: European Stocks On Track For Highest Close In A Week
text:
By Carla Mozee, MarketWatch
European stocks pushed higher Wednesday, on track for their best close in a week, following U.S. and Asian markets higher on the prospect of the Federal Reserve will hold off from a rate hike.
The Stoxx Europe 600 rose 1.1% to 360.07, with all but the basic materials group posting gains.
In Asian trading, Chinese stocks surged by the most in nearly three weeks (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/asian-stock-markets-bounce-back-ahead-of-fed-meeting-2015-09-16). U.S. stocks jumped Tuesday, with some analysts attributing the move to expectations the Fed will leave interest rates at their record low levels. The central bank's two-day policy meeting begins Wednesday, with the decision expected Thursday.
"But before the Fed shows its hand tomorrow, we see U.S. CPI data today, which could move the dollar," said Angus Campbell, senior analyst at FxPro, in a note. "Either way, the data is unlikely to be a game changer, as the overall U.S. inflation picture does not cry out for higher interest rates."
In Frankfurt, Germany's DAX 30 was up 1% to 10,285.50. In Paris, the CAC 40 popped up 1.4% to 4,632.47.
The U.K.'s FTSE 100 gained 0.8% to 6,186.88.
In currencies, the pound jumped to $1.5415 after the release of U.K. jobs data for July. Britain's unemployment rate came in at 5.5%, lower than the 5.6% expected. Average wages, both including and excluding bonuses, rose 2.9%. The pound was buying $1.5344 ahead of the data, and traded at $1.5388 late Tuesday.
Movers: SAP SE (SAP.XE) gained 2.6% following an ratings upgrade to overweight from neutral at J.P. Morgan. The German software maker has made it through the toughest part of its cloud transition, and "margins will trough this year and then gradually increase" about 50 basis points to 60 basis points each year over the next five years, said analyst Stacy Pollard in a research note.
Inditex (ITX.MC), the company behind fashion retailer Zara, bounced up 3% as the company said a weaker euro helped sales rise 17% in the first half of its fiscal year (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/inditex-profit-boosted-by-weak-euro-2015-09-16-14853212). Profit climbed 26%.
 16, 2015 05:11 ET (09:11
